G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and the equitable powers of this Court, the Plaintiff states that there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the original custody order that warrants modification to better serve the best interests of the children.

G.L. c. 209B.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act, G.L. c. 209B, as this matter pertains to the custody and care of children who presently reside in Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

**Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: It undermines the cooperative framework necessary for shared legal custody, as recognized in **Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)**.
**Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition characterizes shared legal custody as requiring a cooperative framework between parents, and argues that a given action (like unilateral relocation) undermines that framework. Mason v. Coleman expressly describes joint custody—especially shared physical custody—as dependent on the parents’ ability and willingness to cooperate, communicate, and subordinate some personal preferences for the arrangement to work. That language recognizes the need for, and potential undermining of, a cooperative framework in joint custody, so the case supports the proposition.
**Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “Although the General Laws state that there is no presumption ‘either in favor or against shared . . . custody at the time of trial on the merits,’ … such an arrangement is generally appropriate only if the parties demonstrate an ability and desire to cooperate amicably and communicate with one another to raise the children…. ‘[I]n order to be effective “joint custody requires ... a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions in a manner similar to the way married couples make decisions.”’ … Shared physical custody in particular carries with it substantial obligation for cooperation between the parents.”

**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass..proposition: It has begun to negatively impact the children, contrary to their best interests as defined in **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985)**.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: Yannas addresses the standard for removal of children from the Commonwealth and defines how to determine their best interests in that context, but it does not state or apply any rule about a situation that “has begun to negatively impact the children.” The opinion explains a multi-factor ‘best interests’/‘real advantage’ analysis, focusing on potential effects of relocation and the custodial parent’s well-being, not on deterioration or new negative impacts after an order. Thus, citing Yannas for the proposition that something “has begun to negatively impact the children, contrary to their best interests as defined in Yannas” mischaracterizes the case’s holding.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

**Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: The Defendant’s actions represent a failure to uphold duties of joint custody and parental cooperation under Massachusetts law, as described in **Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006)**.
**Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The opinion in Pizzino v. Miller concerns a custodial parent’s request to remove children from Massachusetts and applies the Yannas ‘real advantage’ / best-interests removal framework. It does not discuss the substantive duties of joint legal custody, joint physical custody, or a generalized duty of parental cooperation under Massachusetts law. Any references to the mother’s lack of cooperation (e.g., not informing the father of certain matters) are fact-specific and related to removal and contempt, not an articulation of general ‘duties of joint custody and parental cooperation,’ so this case does not provide doctrinal support for that proposition.
**Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: “The judgment assigned physical custody of the children to the mother while providing for reasonable visitation by the father, and placed legal custody of the children in the parents jointly. … In evaluating the mother’s proposed move, the judge gave weight to the possibility that the move was inspired, at least in part, by the mother’s desire to separate the children from the father. In this regard, the judge found that the mother kept the father uninformed on various subjects and did not encourage the children to communicate with him.”

**Bindra v. Bindra, 91 Mass. App. Ct. 72.proposition: The children’s best interests, as the paramount standard in custody determinations, see **Bindra v. Bindra, 91 Mass. App. Ct. 725 (2017)**, require that their emotional well-being and consistent routine be prioritized.

**Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)**.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that custodial modifications are appropriate where changes in circumstances affect the children’s welfare. See **Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)**; **Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)**.
**Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)**.support_reasoning: The opinion applies the familiar Massachusetts standard that custody determinations turn on the child’s best interests and discusses the impact on Jill of changed circumstances (Rose’s move to Oregon/Michigan, multiple caregivers, efforts to alienate Jill from Hunter). While the case is not framed as a classic "modification" of an existing custody judgment, the Court affirms a custody allocation that explicitly weighs how changed living arrangements and parental conduct affect the child’s welfare. Thus it is reasonably supportive of the broader proposition that custody changes are appropriate when circumstances affecting the child’s welfare change, though it is not a paradigmatic modification case like Rolde.
**Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)**.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is]… what is ‘best for the child’…. The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”

**Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that custodial modifications are appropriate where changes in circumstances affect the children’s welfare. See **Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)**; **Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)**.
**Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: Rolde is a direct-appeal divorce/custody case, not a post‑judgment custody modification case. The opinion discusses the best-interests standard and the judge’s discretion in making an initial custody award and visitation order, but it does not address modification of an existing custody judgment based on a material change in circumstances. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that custody modifications are appropriate when circumstances change affecting the children’s welfare.
**Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare.… It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the children in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future, and it is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.” 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 402-03.

**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31**.proposition: The Defendant’s behavior has disrupted the co-parenting dynamic necessary for shared legal custody, creating an environment that is not conducive to the children’s best interests as required by **G.L. c. 208, § 31**.
